name: Maasai
description: Known for their colorful attire, beadwork, and warrior traditions. The Maasai are semi-nomadic pastoralists famous for their Morans who adorn red ochre.

name: Kikuyu
description: The largest ethnic group in Kenya, known for agriculture, music, and folklore about Gikuyu and Mumbi. Family and land are central to Kikuyu culture.

name: Luo
description: Renowned for fishing traditions, storytelling, and music. The Luo have a strong oral history and vibrant cultural ceremonies.

name: Luhya
description: Known for their energetic isukuti dance, farming traditions, and deep sense of community and respect for elders.

name: Kalenjin
description: Famous for producing world-class long-distance runners and valuing cattle, initiation ceremonies, and oral poetry.

name: Kamba
description: Known for woodcarving, storytelling, and traditional healing. The Akamba are skilled traders and craftsmen.

name: Meru
description: Closely related to the Kikuyu, the Meru people are known for farming, circumcision ceremonies, and clan-based governance.

name: Embu
description: Traditionally farmers and storytellers, the Embu share rich oral traditions and rituals celebrating unity and harvest.

name: Somali
description: Pastoralists of the northeastern region known for poetry, camel herding, and Islamic cultural heritage.

name: Turkana
description: Semi-nomadic pastoralists known for beadwork, cattle culture, and strong adaptation to arid environments.

name: Samburu
description: Close cousins to the Maasai, the Samburu are proud pastoralists known for their colorful attire and dance traditions.

name: Pokot
description: A proud highland and lowland community famous for cattle herding, traditional songs, and respect for elders.

name: Taita
description: Residing in the Taita Hills, they are known for farming, pottery, and music reflecting harmony with nature.

name: Taveta
description: Found near the Tanzanian border, the Taveta are traders and farmers blending Swahili and local customs.

name: Borana
description: An Oromo-speaking pastoralist group known for their Gadaa system of governance and strong Islamic traditions.

name: Rendille
description: Nomadic herders living in northern Kenya, recognized for camel culture, unique hairstyles, and jewelry.

name: Giriama
description: Part of the Mijikenda, the Giriama are known for kaya forests, traditional drumming, and resistance to colonial rule.

name: Swahili
description: Coastal people influenced by Arab and African heritage, known for architecture, poetry, and the Kiswahili language.

name: Kuria
description: A community on the Kenyaâ€“Tanzania border known for cattle keeping, elaborate initiation, and traditional dances.

name: Tharaka
description: Closely related to the Meru, they preserve unique folklore, proverbs, and rituals celebrating life and community.
